meta.use_limitations: This report is a decision-support diagnostic. It is not a psychological, medical, or psychiatric assessment.
meta.data_ethics_note: Results should be interpreted by qualified professionals within an organizational or educational context.
meta.what_it_measures: Decision integrity, ethical boundary management, manipulation awareness, attention control, power handling, and correction readiness.
meta.what_it_does_not_measure: Personality traits, intelligence, emotional disorders, or mental health conditions.
meta.limitations: Results depend on contextual pressure, self-report accuracy, and situational variables at the time of assessment.

exec.thesis_sentence: Decisive delivery under pressure with emerging risk of procedural exception normalization and reduced openness to correction when time constraints dominate.

tables.exec_dimensions_rows: Decision Integrity (DI)3.40Functional StrengthDecision logic clarity, criteria discipline, defensibility under scrutiny. Consistently strong signal in typical conditions.Responsibility & Ownership (RP)4.00Functional StrengthOwnership, accountability, responsibility alignment. Consistently strong signal in typical conditions.Manipulation Awareness (MA)3.00Mixed / Context-dependentResistance to authority pressure, manipulation cues, social influence. Performance varies under pressure and context.Attention Control (AC)3.10Mixed / Context-dependentAttention filtering, prioritization, noise vs signal separation. Performance varies under pressure and context.Power & Correction (PR)2.90Mixed / Context-dependentOpenness to correction, dissent bandwidth, power/ego management. Performance varies under pressure and context.Ethical Drift Resistance (ED)2.70Risk ZoneEthical boundary stability, exception tolerance, drift risk. Elevated risk signal; requires guardrails and expert attention.

lists.exec_top_assets_li:
• Clear ownership of outcomes and accountability mindset
  • Ability to execute and prioritize under ambiguity
lists.exec_top_risks_li:
• Ethical drift risk through repeated procedural exceptions
  • Feedback channel narrowing during crisis decision cycles
lists.exec_30day_actions_li:
• Introduce decision logs for any exception (who/why/impact/compensating controls)
  • Implement a structured dissent step for high-stakes calls (2-minute challenge rule)
lists.hr_strengths_safeguards_li:
• Clear ownership of outcomes and accountability mindset
  • Ability to execute and prioritize under ambiguity
lists.hr_development_actions_li:
• Ethical drift risk through repeated procedural exceptions
  • Feedback channel narrowing during crisis decision cycles
lists.hr_interventions_li:
• Introduce decision logs for any exception (who/why/impact/compensating controls)
  • Implement a structured dissent step for high-stakes calls (2-minute challenge rule)
lists.academic_reflection_prompts_li:
• Which decision criteria remain stable under extreme pressure?
  • Where do personal judgment and formal governance diverge?
  • How do power dynamics shape openness to correction?

blocks.exec_red_flags:
• RF_ETH_01: Procedural exception normalization
  • RF_PWR_02: Reduced openness to correction under time pressure
blocks.hr_risks:
• Procedural exception normalization
  • Reduced openness to correction under time pressure
blocks.academic_frameworks: This profile can be interpreted through decision hygiene, authority bias mitigation, and governance guardrails frameworks.
blocks.academic_cc_details: • CC insights available in the draft assessment.

academic.profile_statement: A pragmatic decision-maker balancing speed with governance guardrails.
academic.tradeoffs: Speed and autonomy vs. correction bandwidth and procedural rigor.
academic.cc_overview: Consistency checks indicate pressure-driven variability in ethical boundary tolerance.

hr.role_fit_summary: Strong operational fit; recommend governance reinforcement and feedback loop strengthening for crisis contexts.
